ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I (re)learned some of the most important aspects of Latin grammar and became better at translating longer text. I also learned a bit about Roman history.
Deepened my understanding of Latin, and a great introduction to the prose of Cicero, also some excellent insights into Roman politics and social dynamics of the time.

I further developed my grasp in Latin prose and made a first foray into Latin forensic poetry through the course's focus on Cicero's speech Pro Caelio. We reviewed difficult grammatical concepts and explored Cicero's uses of different rhetorical devices.

This course was based in translating Ciceros Pro Caelio with periodic grammar reviews of certain concepts, but this text is really a medium to discuss grammar, literary themes and Roman culture, all of which come very interesting to light.
This course was a great foundation for reading Latin literature.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would have preferred a variety of texts as we had toward the end of the semester instead of staying with Cicero for most of the time. We could have gotten a good sense for his writing from 10 chapters instead of 60-70. I liked the variety of assignments; the papers and projects were a nice break from the weekly translation quizzes which kind of stressed me out.
Honestly there were basically no weaknesses. Loved the course!

The strengths are definitely Prof. Bell and the way she engages her students! I enjoyed coming to class on MWF because there were added components (mini presentations on Roman culture, mini lectures on cum clauses, innovative graded assignments, etc.) that sharpened my knowledge on the language and the ancient world. I'd say the only weakness is that it's a morning class, and sometimes it took a few minutes to get in the groove of translating sentences.

This course was structured incredibly clearly and efficiently for learning, and although it was quite a lot of work, the exams were fair and it was always clear what would be expected so that students could succeed.

I though that this course was absolutely amazing and was really well taught. This course focused on understanding the Latin, but also made sure to discuss all important cultural and social problems that came up.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual presentations by different students worked well. It was nice that everyone had their cameras turned on.
Everything ended up working very well in this class.
The virtual discussions were fine but I would probably have learned better if there were also some short lectures (<10 mins perhaps on the grammar topics) posted to watch and refer back to.

Our discussions felt quite genuine and engaged despite the online format. I do think that it would be easier if in person to keep students engaged and participating without cold-calling, which was sometimes less welcome.
This course did a really great job transitioning to a virtual format! The fact that this class was a taught as a seminar allowed for a lot of engagement!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it is a good course to evaluate your knowledge of Latin and expand it. Also, you more out of it because there are fewer students so you can socialize and discuss the historical meaning of the Latin translation more.

I would not recommend this class to people outside of the classics/clcv majors. Latin is hard and not particularly useful, and you will benefit more from a different language class. The translations for class also took up more time than assignments for any other class.
Yes! Its the next step in studying Latin, but its also a great class, especially with Treasa.

YES, especially with Prof. Bell! She is kind and really engages her students interests. The workload is manageable and the graded assignments are fun! Amusement is also found when reading Cicero, who you'll find is shocking in many ways
Yes I think Professor Bell was great and very understanding.

If you are interested in further advancing your Latin skills, yes. It introduces you to longer and more complicated works as well as the associated analytical practices that philologists have used for generations.

If the student intends on fully immersing in Latin, absolutely. The Pro Caelio is a fantastic read, and though it meant lots of work nearly every day, inside and outside the virtual classroom, it is extremely satisfying and immense progress in understanding Latin is inevitable.
Yes I would definitely recommend this course! I thought this course was really well taught and Professor Bell was amazing!
